title: 107_s2198
content: The Act may be cited as the "Civil War Sesquicentennial Commission Act of 2002". The American Civil War was a defining experience in the development of the United States. People continue to struggle with issues of race, civil rights, federalism, and heritage as legacies of the war. There is a resurgence of interest in the Civil War, evidenced by various publications, exhibits, reenactments, and research organizations. The years 2011 through 2015 mark the sesquicentennial of the Civil War, providing an opportunity for Americans to recall and reflect. The United States Civil War Center at Louisiana State University and the Civil War Institute at Gettysburg College have been designated to plan and facilitate the commemoration of the sesquicentennial of the Civil War. The purpose of this Act is to establish a Civil War Sesquicentennial Commemoration Commission to ensure a suitable national observance of the sesquicentennial and assist in coordinating programs and activities for the observance. The Civil War Sesquicentennial Commemoration Commission aims to ensure an inclusive observance of the Civil War and support educational programs and activities with lasting value. The Civil War Sesquicentennial Commemoration Commission, known as the "Commission," is established to ensure an inclusive observance of the Civil War and support educational programs with lasting value. The composition of the Commission is outlined in the Act. The Commission, composed of 26 members, includes government representatives appointed from various bodies such as the House of Representatives, Senate, Smithsonian Institution, Department of Education, National Endowment for the Humanities, and the Archivist of the United States. The Commission, consisting of 26 members, includes government representatives appointed from various bodies such as the House of Representatives, Senate, Smithsonian Institution, Department of Education, National Endowment for the Humanities, Archivist of the United States, Librarian of Congress, and Director of the National Park Service. Private members appointed by the President after consultation with specific institutions are also part of the Commission. The Commission consists of 26 members, including government representatives from various bodies and private individuals appointed by the President. Among the private members are experts on the Antebellum, Civil War, and Reconstruction eras, with expertise in history, art history, anthropology, cultural geography, sociology, political science, law, and economics. The Commission consists of 26 members appointed for life, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Initial appointments must be made within 60 days of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. GENERAL PROVISIONS. The Commission must hold an initial meeting within 60 days of all members being appointed, subsequent meetings are called by the chairperson. A Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are elected at the initial meeting. A majority of voting members form a quorum, and decisions require a majority vote. Nonvoting members do not participate in voting. Nonvoting members appointed under section 4(a)(1) serve in an advisory capacity on the Commission. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is responsible for planning and carrying out programs to commemorate the sesquicentennial of the Civil War, encouraging interdisciplinary examination, facilitating related activities nationwide, coordinating scholarly research distribution, and providing technical assistance for commemoration efforts. The Commission is tasked with developing programs and facilities for the sesquicentennial commemoration of the Civil War, administering grant programs, and encouraging international involvement. They are also required to prepare strategic plans and submit a final report to Congress by December 30, 2015. The Commission is responsible for organizing Civil War commemoration programs, managing funds, and making recommendations. They must submit a final report to Congress with a summary of activities, financial accounting, findings, and recommendations. The Commission will award grants to the United States Civil War Center at Louisiana State University and the Civil War Institute at Gettysburg College. Grants will range from $80,000 to $100,000 annually for activities related to the sesquicentennial of the Civil War. The Commission also has powers outlined in Section 8. The Commission, as outlined in Section 8, has the power to solicit, accept, and use gifts or donations, appoint advisory committees, authorize actions by members or employees, and procure supplies and services. Additionally, the Commission can use the United States mails like other federal agencies. Members of the Commission and any advisory committee appointed under section 8(a)(2) serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The Commission may appoint personnel as needed, with the executive director requiring confirmation. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. The Chairperson can also procure temporary services at specified rates. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. $500,000 is authorized annually for the Act until 2015, with funds remaining available until expended. Any unspent appropriations as of December 30, 2015, will be canceled by December 30, 2020.
